title: 103_hr2454
content: The "Procurement Efficiency Act of 1993" may be cited as the Act. It establishes an online database of federal procurement opportunities. The "Procurement Efficiency Act of 1993" establishes a computerized data base of information on federal procurements and subcontracts to be publicly available online. The Secretary of Commerce will establish a data base for federal procurements and subcontracts to be available online within one year of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 amends the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act to include taxpayer identification numbers of contractors in procurement records and requires executive agencies to share these records. Each agency must make these records available to other agencies. SEC. 4 increases the small purchase threshold. SEC. 4 increases the small purchase threshold from $25,000 to $100,000 and removes the requirement of procurement notices for all competitive procurements exceeding the small purchase threshold. SEC. 5 clarifies the authority for procurement regulations. SEC. 5 clarifies the authority for procurement regulations by requiring each regulation to include a citation of the specific statutory authority. SEC. 6 involves the representation of the Small Business Administration on the Cost Accounting Standards Board. Section 20(a)(1) of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to increase the number of representatives on the board, including one from the Small Business Administration. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code is amended to include a new subsection requiring agencies to transmit proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. The proposed rule does not require an initial regulatory flexibility analysis under section 603. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can submit a statement of opposition within 15 days of receiving the proposed rule and analysis. If a statement of opposition is submitted, the agency must publish it along with their response in the Federal Register. The proposed rule does not require an initial regulatory flexibility analysis under section 603. Section 603(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended in accordance with section 612(d). SEC. 8. REVIEW OF DEVIATIONS FROM PROCUREMENT NOTICE REQUIREMENT. The Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to require justification for not providing notice before issuing a procurement solicitation. The Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy will review the justifications to ensure they are appropriate and reasonable, with a mandatory review every 5 years. The Administrator will review justifications for not providing notice before issuing a procurement solicitation, focusing on submissions from the same agency over 5 years to ensure appropriateness. Effective after 30 days from enactment, this amendment applies to solicitations issued thereafter.
